Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Engineering of Functionality Graded Magnesium Composite Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop the processing science for mechanical surface generation so as to enable engineering of magnesium alloy/composite surfaces with specific microstructures that enhance wear performance. The approach involves analysis of mechanics of large strain deformation underlying the unit interaction fundamental to mechanical surface generation - sliding tool interacting with a workpiece surface. Large strain deformation on the workpiece surface will be characterized, in situ, as a function of controllable process variables using advanced experimental mechanics techniques. Microstructure and properties of the surface will be analyzed at multiple length scales using electron microscopy, micro-tensile test, and micro/nano tribology methods, resulting in deformation-microstructure-property maps. Finite element analysis incorporating grain-level plasticity will be used to predict and optimize the deformation in order to create graded surface microstructures with desirable properties. A predictive framework will be established to engineer wear resistant surfaces by control of process variables. Surface generation processes of wide-ranging interest to the discrete products sector including burnishing, surface mechanical attrition, microfinishing, wear and friction stir processing will be impacted by this work.

The scientific benefits will be enhanced understanding of deformation phenomena in hexagonal close packed metals and deformation-microstructure-property correlations for structural magnesium alloys. The technological benefits will be new or improved processes for creating magnesium alloy surfaces with novel attributes enabling development of ultra-lightweight powertrain and structural sub-systems for transportation. Broader impacts include improved fuel economy in automotive, aerospace, or other transportation systems and concomitant environmental benefits; and a strong educational component that will contribute towards a workforce competent in advanced processes and structural materials for industrial applications. The education and training program also includes graduate student internships in industry, undergraduate research training for physically challenged students via collaboration with the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, Rochester Institute of Technology, and a modest focus on fostering entrepreneurship in graduate study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have studied surface deformation processing of magnesium alloys and related metal systems, using a model experimental configuration involving sliding of a hard wedge indenter against the metal surface. This model captures key features of plastic flow and deformation that occur in deformation processes such as machining, sliding, burnishing, peening and friction stir processing. The principal requirements in these manufacturing processes is creation of high quality surfaces with good finish, and reduced levels of surface defects like cracks, tears etc.

Several findings of both scientific and technological interest have emerged from this study. Firstly, a new mode of surface plastic deformation – sinuous flow – characterized by significant material rotation and large-amplitude material folding was uncovered. This flow is highly unsteady and involves significant energy dissipation. It is quite prevalent in cutting of soft metals and high strain hardening metals like copper, aluminum, iron, stainless steels and tantalum. The nature of this flow has helped explain why these metals. although soft, are very difficult to cut, characterized by large forces and poor surface quality. Secondly, we have characterized the evolution of another type of unsteady flow – shear banding - also deleterious for manufacturing processes. In particular we have highlighted attributes of the evolution phase of shear bands in processing. This phase is characterized by a high level of straining – in fact, in excess of 90% of the shear band strain is developed in this evolution phase. Thirdly, both types of unsteady flow, sinuous and shear band flows, can be suppressed by application of a suitable surface constraint on the deformation located across from the primary tool. This suppression of unsteady flow modes by constrained cutting – a form of hybrid extrusion-cutting – has enabled improvements in surface quality as measured in terms of surface finish, surface microstructure and uniformity of mechanical properties. It has also helped catalyze development of a new single-stage process for making sheet metals from difficult to process alloys such as magnesium, titanium and nickel. This single-stage process is efficient in terms of energy, equipment infrastructure and production economics, compared to the currently preferred process for making sheet metals - rolling. It offers considerable scope also for scaling and efforts are under way to address the scaling aspect for large scale production of metal sheet using this process. On these various topics, we have collaborated closely with a number of companies in the discrete products manufacturing sector, both large and small.

Lastly, a variety of high-speed imaging and image analysis techniques have been developed to study material flow in manufacturing processes. These techniques have enabled the principal findings and process development activity. Equally importantly, the techniques have applications in other related engineering disciplines – study of friction phenomena, fracture of solids and deformation of polymers. Application of one of the imaging techniques has also led to solution of a 400 year old problem in fracture of glasses; this has received widespread attention in both scientific and popular news media.
